text: Job’s Third Speech: A Response to Bildad
Then\f + \fr 9:1 \ft Hebrew “And” \f* Job answered and said,
“Truly I know that \add it is\add* so,
but\f + \fr 9:2 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* how can a human being be just before God?
If he wants to contend with him,
he cannot answer him one \add time\add* in a thousand.
\add He is\add* wise in\f + \fr 9:4 \ft Hebrew “of” \f* heart and mighty in\f + \fr 9:4 \ft Hebrew “of” \f* strength;
who has resisted him and succeeded?\f + \fr 9:4 \ft Literally “he succeeded” \f*
“\add He is the one\add* who moves mountains, and they do not know \add how\add*,
who overturns them in his anger.
\add He is the one\add* who shakes \add the\add* earth from its place,
and its pillars tremble.
\add He is the one\add* who commands the sun, and it does not rise,
⸤and he seals up the stars⸥.\f + \fr 9:7 \ft Literally “and behind \fq the \ft stars he seals up” \f*
\add He is the one\add* who alone stretches out \add the\add* heavens
and \add who\add* tramples on \add the\add* waves of \add the\add* sea.
\add He is the one\add* who made \add the\add* Bear \add and\add* Orion,
\add the\add* Pleiades and \add the\add* constellations of \add the\add* south.
\add He is the one\add* who does great things ⸤beyond understanding⸥\f + \fr 9:10 \ft Literally “until there is not understanding” \f*
and marvelous things ⸤beyond number⸥.\f + \fr 9:10 \ft Literally “until there is not number” \f*
“⸤If⸥\f + \fr 9:11 \ft Literally “Look” \f* he passes by me, ⸤I would not see him⸥;\f + \fr 9:11 \ft Literally “and I would not see” \f*
and \add if\add* he should move on, ⸤I would not recognize him⸥.\f + \fr 9:11 \ft Literally “and I would not recognize him” \f*
⸤If⸥\f + \fr 9:12 \ft Literally “Look” \f* he would snatch away, who could turn him?
Who could say to him, ‘What are you doing?’
God will not turn back his anger;
beneath him the helpers of Rahab bow.
⸤How much less⸥\f + \fr 9:14 \ft Literally “Also for” \f* can I myself\f + \fr 9:14 \ft Emphatic personal pronoun \f* answer him?
\add How\add* can I choose my words with him,
whom I cannot answer, even though I am righteous?
From\f + \fr 9:15 \ft Hebrew “To” \f* my judge I must implore grace.
If I summon \add him\add*, and he should answer me,
I do not believe that he will listen to my voice—
who crushes me with a tempest
and multiplies\f + \fr 9:17 \ft Hebrew “he multiplies” \f* my wounds without cause.
He will not allow me to ⸤catch⸥\f + \fr 9:18 \ft Literally “return,” or “regain” \f* my breath;
rather, he will fill me with bitterness.
If ⸤it is a matter of⸥\f + \fr 9:19 \ft Literally “for”; see NASB, NIV, NET \f* strength, look, \add he is\add* mighty.
But\f + \fr 9:19 \ft Hebrew “And” \f* if ⸤it is a matter of⸥\f + \fr 9:19 \ft Literally “for”; NASB, NIV, NET, NRSV \f* justice, who can summon me?\f + \fr 9:19 \ft Or “arraign me” \f*
Even though I am righteous, my mouth will condemn me;
\add even though\add* I \add am\add* blameless, yet\f + \fr 9:20 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* it would pronounce me guilty.
“I \add am\add* blameless; I do not care about myself;\f + \fr 9:21 \ft Perhaps the meaning is “but it makes no difference to me” (NLT) \f*
I loathe my life.
It \add is all\add* one; therefore I say,
‘He destroys \add both the\add* blameless and \add the\add* wicked.’
When the whip\f + \fr 9:23 \ft Or “scourge” \f* kills suddenly,
he mocks at \add the\add* despair of \add the\add* innocent.
The earth is given into \add the\add* hand of \add the\add* wicked;
he covers the face of its judge—
if \add it is\add* not \add he\add*, then who \add is\add* it?
“And my days are swifter than a runner;
they flee away; they do not see good.
They go by like papyrus skiffs,
like an eagle swoops down on \add its\add* prey.
Though\f + \fr 9:27 \ft Or “If” \f* ⸤I say⸥,\f + \fr 9:27 \ft Literally “my saying” \f* ‘I will forget my complaint;
I will change my expression, and I will rejoice,’
I become afraid of all my sufferings;
I know that you do not consider me innocent.
\add If\add* I shall be \add declared\add* guilty,
why then should I labor in vain?
If I wash myself with soap,\f + \fr 9:30 \ft Or “with snow,” or “in snow” \f*
and I cleanse my hands with lye,
then you plunge me into the \add slime\add* pit,
and my clothes abhor me.
“For\f + \fr 9:32 \ft Or the emphatic “Indeed” \f* \add he is\add* not a mortal like me \add that\add* I can answer him,
\add that\add* ⸤we can come to trial together⸥.\f + \fr 9:32 \ft Literally “we come together in the justice,” or “we come together in the judgment” \f*
There is no arbiter between us
\add that\add* he might lay his hand on both of us.
May he remove his rod from me,
and let his dread not terrify me;
\add then\add* I would speak and not fear him,\f + \fr 9:35 \ft Hebrew “and I will not fear him” \f*
for ⸤in myself I am not fearful⸥.\f + \fr 9:35 \ft Literally “not so I with me” \f*
